verses.verse: For whoever eats the fat of the animal of which men offer an offering made by fire to the LORD, the person who eats it shall be cut off from his people.
(Gen. 9:4; Lev. 3:17; 17:10-16; 19:26; Deut. 12:23; 1 Sam. 14:33; Ezek. 33:25; Acts 15:20, 29) Moreover you shall not eat any blood in any of your dwellings, whether of bird or beast.
Whoever eats any blood, that person shall be cut off from his people.’ ”
(The Portion of Aaron and His Sons) Then the LORD spoke to Moses, saying,

“Speak to the children of Israel, saying: (Lev. 3:1; 22:21; Ezek. 45:15) ‘He who offers the sacrifice of his peace offering to the LORD shall bring his offering to the LORD from the sacrifice of his peace offering.

(Lev. 3:3, 4, 9, 14) His own hands shall bring the offerings made by fire to the LORD. The fat with the breast he shall bring, that the (Ex. 29:24, 27; Lev. 8:27; 9:21; Num. 6:20) breast may be waved as a wave offering before the LORD.
(Lev. 3:5, 11, 16) And the priest shall burn the fat on the altar, but the (Num. 18:11; Deut. 18:3) breast shall be Aaron’s and his sons’.
(Ex. 29:27; Lev. 7:34; 9:21; Num. 6:20) Also the right thigh you shall give to the priest as a heave offering from the sacrifices of your peace offerings.
He among the sons of Aaron, who offers the blood of the peace offering and the fat, shall have the right thigh for his part.

For (Ex. 29:28; Lev. 10:14, 15; Num. 18:18, 19; Deut. 18:3) the breast of the wave offering and the thigh of the heave offering I have taken from the children of Israel, from the sacrifices of their peace offerings, and I have given them to Aaron the priest and to his sons from the children of Israel by a statute forever.’ ”
This is the consecrated portion for Aaron and his sons, from the offerings made by fire to the LORD, on the day when Moses presented them to minister to the LORD as priests.
The LORD commanded this to be given to them by the children of Israel, (Ex. 40:13-15; Lev. 8:12, 30) on the day that He anointed them, by a statute forever throughout their generations.

This is the law (Lev. 6:9) of the burnt offering, (Lev. 6:14) the grain offering, (Lev. 6:25) the sin offering, (Lev. 7:1) the trespass offering, (Ex. 29:1; Lev. 6:20) the consecrations, and (Lev. 7:11) the sacrifice of the peace offering,
which the LORD commanded Moses on Mount Sinai, on the day when He commanded the children of Israel (Lev. 1:1, 2; Deut. 4:5) to offer their offerings to the LORD in the Wilderness of Sinai.
(Aaron and His Sons Consecrated) And the LORD spoke to Moses, saying:

(Ex. 29:1-3) “Take Aaron and his sons with him, and (Ex. 28:2, 4) the garments, (Ex. 30:24, 25) the anointing oil, a (Ex. 29:10) bull as the sin offering, two (Ex. 29:15, 19) rams, and a basket of unleavened bread;
and gather all the congregation together at the door of the tabernacle of meeting.”
So Moses did as the LORD commanded him. And the congregation was gathered together at the door of the tabernacle of meeting.
And Moses said to the congregation, “This is what the LORD commanded to be done.”
Then Moses brought Aaron and his sons and (Ex. 30:20; Heb. 10:22) washed them with water.

And he (Ex. 39:1-31) put the tunic on him, girded him with the sash, clothed him with the robe, and put the ephod on him; and he girded him with the intricately woven band of the ephod, and with it tied the ephod on him.
Then he put the breastplate on him, and he (Ex. 28:30; Num. 27:21; Deut. 33:8; 1 Sam. 28:6; Ezra 2:63; Neh. 7:65) put the Urim and the Thummim in the breastplate.
(Ex. 28:36, 37; 29:6) And he put the turban on his head. Also on the turban, on its front, he put the golden plate, the holy crown, as the LORD had commanded Moses.
(Ex. 30:26-29; 40:10, 11; Lev. 8:2) Also Moses took the anointing oil, and anointed the tabernacle and all that was in it, and consecrated them.
He sprinkled some of it on the altar seven times, anointed the altar and all its utensils, and the laver and its base, to consecrate them.
And he (Ex. 29:7; 30:30; Lev. 21:10, 12; Ps. 133:2) poured some of the anointing oil on Aaron’s head and anointed him, to consecrate him.
(Ex. 29:8, 9) Then Moses brought Aaron’s sons and put tunics on them, girded them with sashes, and put hats on them, as the LORD had commanded Moses.
(Ex. 29:10; Ps. 66:15; Ezek. 43:19) And he brought the bull for the sin offering. Then Aaron and his sons (Lev. 4:4) laid their hands on the head of the bull for the sin offering,

and Moses killed it. (Ex. 29:12, 36; Lev. 4:7; Ezek. 43:20, 26; (Heb. 9:22)) Then he took the blood, and put some on the horns of the altar all around with his finger, and purified the altar. And he poured the blood at the base of the altar, and consecrated it, to make atonement for it.
(Ex. 29:13; Lev. 4:8) Then he took all the fat that was on the entrails, the fatty lobe attached to the liver, and the two kidneys with their fat, and Moses burned them on the altar.
But the bull, its hide, its flesh, and its offal, he burned with fire outside the camp, as the LORD (Ex. 29:14; Lev. 4:11, 12) had commanded Moses.
(Ex. 29:15) Then he brought the ram as the burnt offering. And Aaron and his sons laid their hands on the head of the ram,
and Moses killed it. Then he sprinkled the blood all around on the altar.
And he cut the ram into pieces; and Moses (Lev. 1:8) burned the head, the pieces, and the fat.

Then he washed the entrails and the legs in water. And Moses burned the whole ram on the altar. It was a burnt sacrifice for a sweet aroma, an offering made by fire to the LORD, (Ex. 29:18) as the LORD had commanded Moses.
